G.L. c. 218, \u00a7 19.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to G.L. c. 218, § 19 and G.L. c. 223A, § 3, as the events and injuries giving rise to this action occurred within the Commonwealth of Massachusetts and within the judicial district of this Court.

G.L. c. 223A, \u00a7 3.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to G.L. c. 218, § 19 and G.L. c. 223A, § 3, as the events and injuries giving rise to this action occurred within the Commonwealth of Massachusetts and within the judicial district of this Court.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 1.proposition: Venue is proper in this Court under G.L. c. 223, § 1 because the tortious acts and resulting injuries occurred in Newton, Massachusetts.

G.L. c. 140, \u00a7\u00a7 155\u2013157.proposition: Whiting Park is a public park where dogs are required to be kept on leashes, as posted by signage at multiple entrances, pursuant to Newton City Ordinances and G.L. c. 140, §§ 155–157.

Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141 (2006).proposition: To state a claim for negligence under Massachusetts law, a plaintiff must establish that (a) the defendant owed the plaintiff a duty of reasonable care, (b) the defendant breached that duty, (c) the plaintiff suffered actual damage, and (d) the breach was the cause of the damage.
Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141 (2006).support_reasoning: The opinion squarely states the elements of a negligence claim under Massachusetts law in terms that match the proposition. It explains that to prevail on negligence a plaintiff must prove duty, breach, damage, and causal relation between breach and damage, and then applies that framework to the case. This directly supports the cited proposition as an accurate statement of Massachusetts negligence elements.
Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141 (2006).relevant_excerpt: "To prevail on a negligence claim, a plaintiff must prove that the defendant owed the plaintiff a duty of reasonable care, that the defendant breached this duty, that damage resulted, and that there was a causal relation between the breach of the duty and the damage. See J.R. Nolan & L.J. Sartorio, Tort Law § 11.1 (3d ed. 2005)."

Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694 (2000).proposition: To state a claim for negligence under Massachusetts law, a plaintiff must establish that (a) the defendant owed the plaintiff a duty of reasonable care, (b) the defendant breached that duty, (c) the plaintiff suffered actual damage, and (d) the breach was the cause of the damage.
Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694 (2000).support_reasoning: The opinion expressly states the elements the plaintiffs must prove for their negligence claims: breach of a duty to use reasonable care, actual loss (damage), and causation, while elsewhere in the opinion the existence of a duty is discussed as a necessary predicate. Although framed in terms of the issues in this particular case, the court is clearly applying the familiar Massachusetts negligence framework of duty, breach, damages, and causation, and cites the Restatement and a tort treatise for that standard.
Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694 (2000).relevant_excerpt: With respect to each such claim, the plaintiffs bear the burden of proving that the defendant committed a breach of the duty to use reasonable care, that the plaintiffs suffered actual loss, and that the defendant’s negligence caused their loss. See Restatement (Second) of Torts § 281 (1965); J.R. Nolan & L.J. Sartorio, Tort Law § 204 (2d ed. 1989). Causation is an essential element of that proof.

Andrews v. Jordan Marsh Co., 283 Mass. 1.raw_text: Andrews v. Jordan Marsh Co., 283 Mass. 158 (1933)
Andrews v. Jordan Marsh Co., 283 Mass. 1.proposition: Defendant owed Plaintiff a duty to control his animal and to act as a reasonable person under the circumstances, including compliance with applicable leash ordinances and statutes.
Andrews v. Jordan Marsh Co., 283 Mass. 1.support_reasoning: The case concerns a store’s premises-liability duty regarding a dog that was not owned or controlled by the defendant, not a defendant’s duty as an owner/keeper to control his own animal or comply with leash ordinances. The court explicitly notes there was no statute or ordinance requiring dogs in Boston to be leashed and declines to consider the effect of such laws, then applies common-law principles for ordinarily harmless animals. Thus, the opinion does not establish a duty to control one’s animal via leash or statute in the way the proposition states.
Andrews v. Jordan Marsh Co., 283 Mass. 1.relevant_excerpt: "The plaintiff can recover only upon proof of breach of the defendant’s duty to keep the premises in safe condition for her use as a customer. Reasonable care to keep the premises safe for customers from harm caused by animals is within the scope of this duty... No statute, in the absence of facts not here shown... and no order or ordinance, so far as the evidence shows, requires dogs in Boston to be kept on leash or otherwise restrained... and we need not consider the effect of such a statute, order or ordinance."

Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973).proposition: Defendant owed Plaintiff a duty to control his animal and to act as a reasonable person under the circumstances, including compliance with applicable leash ordinances and statutes.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973).support_reasoning: The provided excerpt from Mounsey v. Ellard is a concurrence discussing the abolition of common-law status distinctions among entrants (invitee, licensee, trespasser) and does not address duties relating to control of animals, leash laws, or statutes governing animals. Nothing in this passage (or in the core holding of Mounsey, which concerns occupiers’ liability) establishes a specific duty to control an animal or to comply with leash ordinances. Therefore, this case does not support the proposition claimed.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973).relevant_excerpt: The court holds that the measure of responsibility of an occupier should no longer depend on whether the injured person is characterized as a “licensee” rather than an “invitee,” or vice versa; the question is to turn on other, more vital factors. But footnote 7 seems to say that “trespassers” stand apart, that that characterization is to remain decisive or highly influential.

Curran v. Burkhardt, 310 Mass. 466 (1941.proposition: Defendant breached this duty by allowing his large dog to run loose in an area where dogs are required to be leashed.
Curran v. Burkhardt, 310 Mass. 466 (1941.support_reasoning: The opinion is a statutory dog-bite/dog-injury case focused on ownership/keeper status and the statutory elements of liability under G.L. c. 140, § 155. It does not discuss any duty to leash a dog, local leash laws, or negligence based on allowing a dog to run loose. Accordingly, it does not provide authority for the proposition that the defendant breached a duty by allowing his dog to run loose where leashes are required.
Curran v. Burkhardt, 310 Mass. 466 (1941.relevant_excerpt: "This is an action of tort under G. L. (Ter. Ed.) c. 140, § 155, as appearing in St. 1934, c. 320, § 18, to recover damages against the defendant as the owner or keeper of a dog which, the plaintiff alleges, seized the leg of his trousers as he was walking in front of the defendant’s premises, and then got between his legs, causing him to fall to the sidewalk with such violence as to fracture his hip…. The sole contention of the defendant is that he was not responsible for the acts of the dog that attacked the plaintiff."

Abramian v. President & Fellows of Harva.raw_text: Abramian v. President & Fellows of Harvard College, 432 Mass. 107 (2000)
Abramian v. President & Fellows of Harva.proposition: Defendant’s breach of duty directly and proximately caused Plaintiff’s injuries.
Abramian v. President & Fellows of Harva.case_name: Abramian v. President & Fellows of Harvard College
Abramian v. President & Fellows of Harva.support_reasoning: The opinion is an employment discrimination/retaliation and intentional interference case and does not analyze or apply the tort standard of direct and proximate causation for personal injuries. While the court notes that Abramian was harmed and that the defendants’ conduct led to his termination and emotional distress, it does not set out or discuss a rule on breach of duty directly and proximately causing injuries. Therefore, it does not serve as authority for the general negligence causation proposition stated.
Abramian v. President & Fellows of Harva.relevant_excerpt: "In an action for wrongful interference with contract the plaintiff must prove that the plaintiff had a contract with a third party, the defendant knowingly induced the third party to break that contract, the defendant’s interference was improper in motive or means, and the plaintiff was harmed by the interference." (Abramian, 432 Mass. at 121-22).

Lane v. Atlantic Works, 111 Mass. 136 (1.proposition: The law recognizes that where an injury results from a person’s reasonable reaction to a foreseeable danger created by another’s negligence, the original wrongdoer remains liable.
Lane v. Atlantic Works, 111 Mass. 136 (1.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely addresses proximate cause and liability where an intervening act occurs, holding that a negligent defendant remains liable if the intervening act was a foreseeable consequence of the original negligence. While the case speaks in terms of foreseeable intervening human acts rather than expressly framing the issue as a victim’s ‘reasonable reaction to danger,’ the same principle of liability for foreseeable responses to the defendant’s negligence is applied and affirmed. Thus it provides supporting authority for the proposition, though not in those exact words.
Lane v. Atlantic Works, 111 Mass. 136 (1.relevant_excerpt:
"In actions of this description, the defendant is liable for the natural and probable consequences of his negligent act or omission. The injury must be the direct result of the misconduct charged; but it will not be considered too remote if, according to the usual experience of mankind, the result ought to have been apprehended.
The act of a third person, intervening and contributing a condition necessary to the injurious effect of the original negligence, will not excuse the first wrongdoer, if such act ought to have been foreseen. The original negligence still remains a culpable and direct cause of the injury."

Tuttle v. Atlantic City R.R. Co., 145 Ma.raw_text: Tuttle v. Atlantic City R.R. Co., 145 Mass. 175 (1887)
Tuttle v. Atlantic City R.R. Co., 145 Ma.proposition: The law recognizes that where an injury results from a person’s reasonable reaction to a foreseeable danger created by another’s negligence, the original wrongdoer remains liable.
Tuttle v. Atlantic City R.R. Co., 145 Ma.case_name: Tuttle v. George H. Gilbert Manufacturing Co.
Tuttle v. Atlantic City R.R. Co., 145 Ma.support_reasoning: The opinion deals with landlord liability and the distinction between contract and tort, focusing on whether a mere failure to make promised repairs can support a negligence action. It does not discuss injuries caused by a plaintiff’s reasonable reaction to a foreseeable danger, nor does it address proximate cause in that context. Therefore, it provides no authority for the proposition about liability for injuries resulting from a person’s reasonable reaction to a danger created by another’s negligence.
Tuttle v. Atlantic City R.R. Co., 145 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “The action of tort has for its foundation the negligence of the defendant, and this means more than a mere breach of a promise… As a general rule, there must be some active negligence or misfeasance to support tort. There must be some breach of duty distinct from breach of contract… If the defendant had performed the work contemplated by its contract unskilfully and negligently, it would be liable to an action of tort, because in such case there would be a misfeasance…”

Conners v. Northeast Hosp. Corp., 439 Ma.raw_text: Conners v. Northeast Hosp. Corp., 439 Mass. 469 (2003)
Conners v. Northeast Hosp. Corp., 439 Ma.proposition: The law recognizes that where an injury results from a person’s reasonable reaction to a foreseeable danger created by another’s negligence, the original wrongdoer remains liable.
Conners v. Northeast Hosp. Corp., 439 Ma.support_reasoning: The opinion in Conners v. Northeast Hosp. Corp. concerns application of Massachusetts’ charitable immunity damages cap and the characterization of the hospital’s activities as charitable or commercial, plus a brief discussion of jury instructions on subcontractor negligence. It does not address any doctrine about liability for injuries resulting from a person’s reasonable reaction to a foreseeable danger created by another’s negligence. There is no discussion of intervening acts, rescue doctrine, or reaction-to-danger principles, so the case does not support the stated proposition.
Conners v. Northeast Hosp. Corp., 439 Ma.relevant_excerpt: We agree with the judge that maintaining the entire hospital campus, including undertaking snow removal on the B-2 parking lot, “accomplish[ed] directly” Northeast’s charitable purposes for at least two reasons. The snow removal activities facilitated the care and treatment of the sick, providing a convenient means of access, i.e., parking, to patients seeking treatment. Additionally, the location of The Medical Building on the campus augmented and enhanced the medical care and treatment offered both to Northeast’s patients and the wider community...

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85.proposition: Defendant’s actions were in violation of G.L. c. 140, §§ 155–157; G.L. c. 231, § 85 (comparative negligence standard); and the City of Newton Animal Control Ordinances requiring leashing of dogs in public parks.

Robbins v. Atkins, 413 Mass. 377 (1992).proposition: Plaintiff’s own conduct was reasonable under the circumstances, as she acted instinctively and prudently to avoid an imminent perceived danger.
Robbins v. Atkins, 413 Mass. 377 (1992).case_name: Alliance, AFSCME/SEIU, AFL-CIO v. Secretary of Administration
Robbins v. Atkins, 413 Mass. 377 (1992).support_reasoning: The opinion is a public-sector labor and appropriations case about whether cost items in collective bargaining agreements became effective without a valid appropriation. It does not address personal injury, negligence, or the reasonableness of a plaintiff’s instinctive conduct in the face of imminent danger. Accordingly, it provides no authority for the proposition that a plaintiff’s own conduct was reasonable because she acted instinctively and prudently to avoid perceived danger.
Robbins v. Atkins, 413 Mass. 377 (1992).relevant_excerpt: “We conclude that the increases have not become effective and are not enforceable. … Since an appropriation requires gubernatorial and legislative action, there have been no ‘appropriations . . . to fully fund the cost items’ since there has been no appropriation bill enacted into law to fund those items.”

Payton v. Abbott Labs, 386 Mass. 540 (19.proposition: Plaintiff is entitled to recover those damages from Defendant pursuant to Massachusetts common law of negligence.
Payton v. Abbott Labs, 386 Mass. 540 (19.support_reasoning: The opinion is a certified-question decision primarily about Massachusetts tort doctrines for emotional distress, prenatal injury, wrongful life, and DES market-share liability. It does assume for purposes of the questions that defendants were negligent and that plaintiffs seek recovery under negligence theories, but it does not hold that any particular plaintiff "is entitled to recover damages" from these defendants; indeed, it denies recovery for emotional distress alone and leaves market-share liability unresolved. Thus, it does not provide affirmative authority that a plaintiff is entitled to recover negligence damages, only that certain negligence-based theories are or are not cognizable under Massachusetts law.
Payton v. Abbott Labs, 386 Mass. 540 (19.relevant_excerpt: "We note initially that neither the issue of negligence nor that of causation is before us. The certified question assumes both that the defendants were negligent, and that their negligence caused the plaintiffs' emotional distress... In summary, we hold that a plaintiff who alleges that she suffered injury in utero as a result of her mother's ingestion of a drug and that, but for the defendant's negligence, her mother would not have ingested that drug, has stated a claim upon which relief can be granted under Massachusetts law."

Ward v. American Mutual Liability Ins. C.raw_text: Ward v. American Mutual Liability Ins. Co., 15 Mass. App. Ct. 98 (1983)
Ward v. American Mutual Liability Ins. C.proposition: Plaintiff is entitled to recover those damages from Defendant pursuant to Massachusetts common law of negligence.
Ward v. American Mutual Liability Ins. C.case_name: Ward v. American Mutual Liability Insurance
Ward v. American Mutual Liability Ins. C.support_reasoning: The case is a contract action about breach of written employment agreements and the effect of the employer’s material breach on enforcement of a non‑competition clause. The court’s analysis and holding are grounded entirely in contract law (material breach and resulting excuse of further performance), not Massachusetts common-law negligence. It does not address negligence elements, duty, breach of a standard of care, or tort damages, so it does not support a proposition about recovering damages under Massachusetts negligence law.
Ward v. American Mutual Liability Ins. C.relevant_excerpt: “Similarly, the defendant’s wrongful discharges of the plaintiffs constituted breaches of the employment agreements so material as to discharge the plaintiffs from any further obligations under the contracts and to allow them to recover contract damages for total breach.”

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B.proposition: B. Awarding costs of this action and interest as allowed by law pursuant to G.L. c. 231, § 6B;
